snippet.textDisplay: My bf is latino, although American. When we first started dating, he always thought my demand for respect and equality from the world was kind of "radical" (I'm black), because unbeknownst to him, he was raised to generally accept racism towards him because it makes you a "good minority" to be agreeable and "grateful " for being here. Whereas being African American, I feel we (justifiably) are more concious and demanding of our rights because we have been here for generations, in many cases longer than our white counterparts. It was an educational experience for the both of us, because I didn't know that there's people who didn't speak up, and he didn't know that he had the right to do so. After 5 years of being together, we're both pretty outspoken about equality.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually disagree with what Amanda was saying @ 3:13... While I think that every body should consider it a duty and a personal responsibility to stand up to injustices they see or know about - jumping into such grotesque situations as this was and recording it as a means of gaining some sort of clout - isn't a very fair or correct insinuation to make. This horrifying video ended up going viral - and it rightfully shocked and incensed people all over the world. Furthermore, it shined a light onto the acrimonious resentment that has been brewing between the black and asian communities - which despite what Amanda might think - it is not something that everyone knows about. Also footage like this will help in aiding the proper authorities with being able to identify the monsters who need to be held responsible for their despicable acts. All I am trying to say is that, if all you are able to do is take a video of the atrocities of an injustice that you happen to be a witness of, then you are doing a big part in helping to stand up to injustice, and I think that you are providing a good and a thank-worthy service.

snippet.textDisplay: I wish people would stop talking in such divisive ways and stop being played by the wealthy elites who benefit from people being divided . Poverty does not care about the color of our skin, nor the % of ethnic groups in a poor community. Poor is poor regardless of our skin color. Stop with this division of "Your People vs My People" "People of Color and excluding White People" White is a color too folks. 😘 Equality exists only when EVERYONE is included. Growing up in a poor community where there where people of every ethnic background what is NEVER addressed is the Poor White folks in the community. When racism is the cause of generational poverty, POC say we are victims of the system that is racist against us, prefers White skin, so its not our fault we are poor, but those Poor White folks in our community "they" must have done something to deserve being poor. Growing up poor, growing up without two parents in the home, growing up without a dad, being a victim of crime/s hurts us all -- the SAME. We all bleed red. We really need to examine our own words and actions and ask ourselves is this bringing people together or causing more division among the people -- our people -- our human race? When "Our People" refers to Everyone from every ethnic background we will defeat the racists haters in this world.

snippet.textDisplay:
Poor guy :/ absolutely heartbreaking. And this damn culture so obsessed with voyeurism, it's truly disturbing how no one stepped in to help.

I appreciate this conversation. And I thank Amanda for contextualizing. I did have a problem with her saying "I don't know what led to this" or something along those lines. It doesn't matter what led to this. Wrong is wrong. Just because the people who did this to this man are black does not take away from it being wrong. Like c'mon, institutional racism creates layers of inequality- but don't remove agency from black folk because that just perpetuates a myth. It wouldn't be right to say "oh I don't know what led to that white calling that black guy the n word" because it doesn't matter. Obviously racism is different than discrimination, but it rubbed me the wrong way when she said that.

snippet.textDisplay: I think people need to truly understand the meaning of racism versus colorism. Racism is a systematic degradation of a people, in economics, education and simple resources.  African Americans are the only ones suffering from that CURRENTLY. Asians have access to quality education, housing, and employment opportunities.  Now whether or not they suffer from colorism is a different story. We cannot equate the struggle, bc it's not the same. Especially considering that both Latinos and Asians look down on African people until they are the ones under fire,  then its unite. I don't wish this treatment on ANYONE, but I also can't agree with it all being in the same category. Not many asians and Latinos slain in the streets these days.....IJS.
